responses.content: Salesforce has had an evolving leadership structure several times, and we have also had tremendous success previously with the Co-CEO structure. These jobs are big jobs and being able to have a partner that you can share it with makes it a lot easier. When Keith decided to retire, I was back in this job. It was very lonely, and now to have a partner with Bret, I couldn't be more excited.

In so many of the CEO conversations that I'm having, and let me emphasize the ones I'm having in Europe, number one, because of the Green New Deal that's happening here in Europe, every CEO here is focused on their net zero transformation, and they realize that for them to continue to be successful in this environment, in this economy, they're having to make a net zero transformation. The second priority is supply chain challenges. The third priority is success from anywhere in this new world...

We've had now three out of the last five quarters greater than 20%, and we have a lot of swagger when it comes to our operating margin. The pandemic let us have a beginner's mind in regards to our entire business, and we made strategic decisions, tactical decisions, and also decisions at our core way that we're operating our business, and you can see that with these operating margin results.

We're in a new world, and we've had the ability to adjust and run the company dynamically. We're in a tremendous new world, and Salesforce has never been better positioned for an economy and for a world. We're continuing to integrate our acquisitions successfully, and Slack has fundamentally changed the tone and tempo and future of Salesforce.

We've certainly seen the software industry contract, and I think it's probably best reflected by that ETF I watch it very closely, IGV. When we made the major decision to acquire Slack more than a year ago, it became our most strategic initiative in the company. It will take us quite a long time to digest this acquisition. We also have other parts of our portfolio that require our focus to ensure they work for our investors.

bret_taylor.role: Vice Chair and Co-Chief Executive Officer

responses.content: We're really excited about this vision for the Slack-First Customer 360, and that's really building not only an integrated vision between Slack and our Customer 360 platform, but also integrating our products. We've made a faster start to integrating our technology than any acquisition in our history. Slack Connect was up an astonishing 176% year-over-year in the quarter...

responses.topic: Cloud Portfolio Performance and Multi-Cloud Deals
responses.content: The strength is really across the portfolio. When we talk about the fact that of the seven-figure deals, they on average included more than four of our clouds; we're not selling individual products. We're selling a Customer 360 solution to really transform the entire customer experience...

responses.topic: Customer Data Platform (CDP) and Marketing Cloud
responses.content: Our Customer Data Platform, branded as Customer 360 Audiences, is powered by Hyperforce architecture. It enables scalable, real-time data integration and provides marketers with deep insights to drive personalized campaigns. In Q4, CDP significantly boosted Marketing Cloud performance, driving higher engagement and conversion rates.

We're really excited about the combination of Slack and Tableau. Automated notifications so that when you need to take action on data, you're getting notified in Slack, you can collaborate with your colleagues to diagnose a business issue, just an incredible combination. It really shows just our philosophy on our M&A and why we've had really unprecedented success in the marketplace and integrating our acquisition successfully...

We've seen tremendous growth and operating margin improvements through discipline and strategic decision-making. This has been facilitated by our new operating model and the integration of Slack, which is now a strategic part of every customer conversation.

We've made some changes that we think are right for the long-term, and while we recognize some short-term growing pains as we integrate our acquisitions, we feel very confident in the future of MuleSoft. It's fundamental to our ability to deliver our Customer 360 and solve customer problems.

amy_weaver.role: President, Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Committee

responses.topic: Balance Between Growth and Margin Expansion
responses.content: When I look at the balance between growth and profitability, I want to be clear that growth remains our number one priority. Investing into growth, especially in this demand environment, is simply the best thing we can do for the company. That said, I am a big believer that a focus on discipline makes for a stronger and more durable company...

We raised our full-year operating margin improvement guide by 50 basis points, from 17.5% to 18%. This improvement comes from a combination of our strong quarterly performance, T&E savings due to the digital work environment, and renewed focus on operational efficiencies and discipline across the company.

The lowest hanging fruit is clearly our difference in how we are working right now. It's this all-digital work from anywhere. Probably the easiest part on that is the difference in T&E. That clearly has gone way down. We are assuming, for purposes of guidance, some modest return of travel in the second half of this year. But it will be nowhere near where we were pre-pandemic...

We use Slack to negotiate, to do â€“ we conducted our due diligence, our negotiation and integration for Slack. So I do think that that's the ultimate example of a terrific sale, all conducted with Slack and Slack Connect.

We've been able to drive growth and increase profitability at the same time through terrific business performance, efficiencies, the work-from-anywhere model, and disciplined decision-making. We're challenging ourselves and finding ways to shift our operating model where necessary.

One of the advantages of breaking up the revenue this way is it provides greater transparency to all of our investors. It will put Tableau and MuleSoft, which are two primarily license-based offerings, together in the same line. It's more about lumpiness in revenue recognition rather than seasonality.

responses.topic: Operating Margin Guidance and Q4 Seasonality
responses.content: We have a great year and I'm really delighted to predict that we're going to end the year around 18.6%. We are expecting additional investments in our workforce and our growth and also some modest increase to T&E expectations in Q4, which will cause a quarter-over-quarter decline in operating margin. But we're really excited about the full-year number and proud to be guiding to 18.6%.

The pipeline is very strong, and we saw that build throughout the year, and coming into Q4 we continued to see it build. And that's in spite of having no face-to-face events during the year. It's all been done digitally...

Slack provides access to rich conversational customer data, advancing our AI efforts. It serves as the operating system for growth, facilitating team selling, customer service, and marketing in the all-digital work-from-anywhere world...

responses.topic: Using Slack in the Sales Process
responses.content: We are beginning to sell through Slack. The most powerful presentation sales teams give are often Salesforce on Salesforce, and so Slack on Slack is a very compelling way to explain how we use the product. We're beginning to do more and more of that...

Our agility allows us to maintain the grip of a small company while managing to grow into a 21-plus billion dollar company. This has been crucial in responding to changing customer needs and delivering transformation solutions...

The pipeline is very strong and continues to build despite the shift to digital engagement. We're investing in our sales force to capture the growing demand and are confident in our ability to meet future opportunities...

responses.topic: Deal Complexity and Time to Value
responses.content: Deal complexity has increased, with more sophisticated and multi-cloud solutions being demanded by customers. Time to value is now a top priority, and we're ensuring that our solutions are deployed quickly and effectively to meet these needs...

We've put a lot more focus on executional excellence and grip on the operating metrics around the pipeline going forward. We've spent a lot of time looking at how everybody in the sales organization is contributing through participation and through enablement, through productivity, and really driving performance across each of the operating units. We've flattened the structure so that we can move in a more agile manner and give more accountability to operating unit leaders.

Geographically, there's strength across the board. The US is consistently growing 20%-plus in revenue. EMEA is growing 32% this quarter, and APAC is growing 26%. So we're growing across the board and growth internationally is not coming at the expense of growth in the US.

We started the fourth quarter really strong, and demand is stronger across the pipeline looks very good. Americas is particularly strong and parts of Europe are performing equally well. There's good performance across the verticals. It's a balanced performance across the board.

We've gone through some operational challenges with MuleSoft, but the actions that need to be taken are very clear. MuleSoft is fundamental to our ability to deliver our Customer 360, and we are confident we'll work through these over the next quarter.
As we cycle through another wave of COVID, I don't see that changing fundamentally. Demand remains strong, and pipeline is robust across all geographies and products.

questions: Are you seeing or can you comment there were some reports of pull forwards of demand for front office applications? Can you just set the stage and maybe give us some context around what you saw in Q4 and kind of as you come out of the pandemic, the strength of pipeline, the demand environment, and your ability to execute on that demand?

On the Co-CEO structure, how do you envision breaking down CEO responsibilities amongst yourselves? And what did you learn in the past about having Co-CEOs that will make this structure even better than it was last time around?

Regarding the guidance for CRPO in Q4, it seems to imply meaningful deceleration. What factors contribute to this? Is there anything anomalous to call out perhaps in addition to FX? And is there anything at all that impacts the confidence level that you have in your forecast?
One of the main exciting points around Slack was the shared channel, especially on the sales side. Can you talk about what you're seeing in the market and the feedback you get from customers?
You've beaten operating margin this quarter. Can you talk a little bit about the linearity of spending in Q4, because this quarter was so much better. Are you spending or hiring quite a bit in Q4?

Can you talk about the degree to which FX impacts are already incorporated into the Q4 guide and to what extent have you incorporated the strong US dollar into the margin commentary and the forward FY 2023 guide?

You've been working on a new philosophy of a better balance between growth and profitability for a couple of quarters now. How is that progressing? Are you finding this to be an easier or harder job than you originally anticipated in terms of pivoting the company to more of an efficiency focus?

What are you measuring to judge success with Slack, beyond revenue growth in terms of the number of customers and multi-cloud deals that include Slack? What should we be looking for to see that the deal is progressing as planned and that it is the one plus one equals seven combination that you guys are betting on?

Bret, I was hoping you could touch on some of the growing pains that were alluded to with MuleSoft. I think you also mentioned that there were some changes made in that business that you feel pretty good about. So maybe just unpack that a little bit.
How should we think about the seasonality and modeling of the data cloud business, just given it's the first time that you are breaking that out?

When you look at the valuation out there in the software market, obviously it's come in quite a bit since the last call. Just how are you thinking about that as you approach M&A? And with valuations having come down so much, does that change your philosophy or framework on how you're approaching M&A given higher IRR and kind of the math?

topics: Strategic Depth and Vertical Tech Stack
questions: Bret, you said that Salesforce is becoming more strategic to the C-Suite just for their broadening footprint. So my question is, and Marc, too, and even Gavin, when you talk to customers, what are they saying to you about, call it, not only the breadth of the CRM portfolio, but also now the depth of the vertical tech stack when choosing Salesforce versus, let's say, point vendors, especially kind of considering the upside we saw in Slack this quarter?
